description.narrative: Strengthening the resilience of institutions and communities to all forms of violence through preventive and women-centred community security approaches

participating-org.narrative: US International Narcotics and Law Enforcement Affairs

description.narrative:
1.1.1 Number of legal frameworks relating to the establishment of community policing (target=2) 1.1.2 Level of operationalization of the governance structure (0= structure not in place, 1=organigramme developed, 2=structure equipped, 3= trainings carried out, 4= structure operational) 1.2.1 Number of ISF trained on the community policing. 1.2.1.2 Number of ISF women trained on the community policing. 1.2.2.1 Number of ISF trained on SGBV prevention. 1.2.2.2 Number of women ISF trained on SGBV prevention. 1.2.3.1 1 Number of technically and financially supported community safety associations SGBV 1.2.4 .1 1 Presence of a complaint management system including SGBV 1.3.1.1 1 Legal Framework for Local Security committees 1.3.2.1 Number of civil society actors supported in the national and international legal framework 1.3.3.1 Number of civil society actors supported in advocacy and communication techniques 1.3.4.1 Existence of a local network of women leaders capable of defining needs and priorities 1.4.1.1 Number of Women ISF Trained in Safety Issues 1.4.1.2 Number of women ISF Trained in PVE 1.4.1.3 Number of women ISF trained in SGBV. 1.4.2.1 Number of round tables organized and allowing for dialogue between ISF, particularly women ISF, with the various members of the local security committees on SGBV and PVE 1.5.1.1 Number of PVE awareness campaigns at regional and national levels 1.5.2.1 Number of publications and/or tools disseminated at local level 1.6.1.1 Number of issues identified through WSA in women’s security 1.6.2.1 Number of associations supported in accordance with the results of the Women safety audit under the SOPs 1.7.1.1 Number of permanent mechanisms for dialogue between women ISF and civil society
1.7.2.1 Number of monitoring committees on local security committees to promote the integration of women’s human security needs into these plans. 2.1.1.1 Independent evaluation of MoI gender mainstreaming needs 2.1.2.1 Report on improving process

comment.narrative: 1.1.1 Number of legal frameworks relating to the establishment of community policing TARGET: 2 1.1.2 Level of operationalization of the governance structure TARGET: 4= structure operational) 1.2.1 Number of ISF trained on the community policing. TARGET: 450 1.2.1.2 Number of ISF women trained on the community policing. TARGET: 150 1.2.2.1 Number of ISF trained on SGBV prevention. TARGET: 450 1.2.2.2 Number of women ISF trained on SGBV prevention. TARGET: 150 1.2.3.1 1 Number of technically and financially supported community safety associations SGBV TARGET: 10 1.2.4 .1 1 Presence of a complaint management system including SGBV TARGET: 100% 1.3.1.1 1 Legal Framework for Local Security committees TARGET: 100% 1.3.2.1 Number of civil society actors supported in the national and international legal framework TARGET: 40 1.3.3.1 Number of civil society actors supported in advocacy and communication techniques TARGET: 400 1.3.4.1 Existence of a local network of women leaders capable of defining needs and priorities TARGET: 1 1.4.1.1 Number of Women ISF Trained in Safety Issues TARGET: 60 1.4.1.2 Number of women ISF Trained in PVE TARGET: 60 1.4.1.3 Number of women ISF trained in SGBV. TARGET: 60 1.4.2.1 Number of round tables organized and allowing for dialogue between ISF, particularly women ISF, with the various members of the local security committees on SGBV and PVE TARGET: 10 1.5.1.1 Number of PVE awareness campaigns at regional and national levels TARGET: 10 1.5.2.1 Number of publications and/or tools disseminated at local level TARGET: 2 1.6.1.1 Number of issues identified through WSA in women’s security TARGET: 6 1.6.2.1 Number of associations supported in accordance with the results of the Women safety audit under the SOPs TARGET: 10 1.7.1.1 Number of permanent mechanisms for dialogue between women ISF and civil society TARGET: 1 1.7.2.1 Number of monitoring committees on local security committees to promote the integration of women’s human security needs into these plans TARGET: 16 2.1.1.1 Independent evaluation of MoI gender mainstreaming needs TARGET: 1 2.1.2.1 Report on improving processes for identifying legal and institutional gaps in order to improve women’s access to high responsibilities TARGET: 1 2.2.1.1 Existence of a sectoral strategy on gender mainstreaming in the MoI TARGET: 100% 2.2.2.1 Number of sector cells and technical committees within the MoI responsible for monitoring this supported strategy TARGET: 15 2.2.2.2 Percentage of key actors such as the Police Academy, the LNFP, the DG for Human Rights, etc. strengthened in the implementation of the sectoral gender mainstreaming strategy for monitoring this supported strategy TARGET: 100% 2.2.3.1 Existence of a specific equal opportunities strategy within the MoI TARGET: 1 2.2.4.1 Existence of a participatory process involving the main units, women members of the ISF TARGET: 1 2.3.1.1 Existence of an MoI sectoral protocol on SGBV and Law 2017-58 TARGET: 1 2.3.2.1 Number of specialized SGBV units supported. TARGET: 128 2.3.3.1 Number of Women ISF Executives Trained TARGET: 16 2.4.1.1 A new recruitment policy within the MoI is developed TARGET: 100% 2.4.2.1 Gender Equality Report/Status will be integrated to improve hiring processes for women TARGET: 1 2.4.3.1 Establishment of a dedicated MoI working group responsible for recruitment processes and internal promotion TARGET: 1 2.4.4.1 Existence of at least one (1) new mechanism for recruiting women staff to the MI TARGET: 1
